author: By Emma Munbodh
title: 10 money-saving travel tips: how to save on flights, sightseeing and hotels abroad
text:
Whether you've splashed out on your holiday, or managed to bag a super-cheap deal last minute, it's now time to stock up on the little extras - like currently exchange, the 10 bikinis you NEED and your sun cream .
Holiday bookings website Skyscanner share their top tips for travelling on a budget below, from how to bag a cheap train ride, to free sight-seeeing.
For more holiday bargains, flash sales and for how to save on everything else travel-related, see our cheap holidays page.
1. Be flexible on dates Flights are often cheaper on the days people prefer NOT to fly, like weekdays.
Always be sure to tick the 'flexible on dates' box when booking - as it'll allow you to see which dates around your chosen time are cheapest.
Websites with this function include budget airline easyJet , Ice Lolly and Thomson Holidays.
2. Embrace local cuisine Use street food markets for lunch instead of dining in restaurants out on the town - and you'll save pounds.
Tripadvisor is one of the best places for local restaurants reviews - plus, you can book your seats well in advance online before you jet off.
3. Ask about student and 60+ discounts If you're studying, always ask for student discount; they may not advertise it but they may offer it.
4. Check currency rates well in advance Getting your currency converted at a better rate can save you loads of cash. Shop around for the best rates, and start checking out prices at least a month before you travel.
For help on how to find the best price, see our guide on the secrets to the best rates or our tips on how to use prepaid currency cards .
5. Book a B&B Book a hotel with breakfast included. It may cost a little extra, but eating your money's worth in the morning or making sandwiches for later will save you money on lunch and snacks.
For B&B's on a budget, see Tripadvisor for the best 30 hotels in every city.
6. Go on a free city walking tour Go on a free city walking tour - they're a great way to get your bearings in a new place, and some even offer free snacks or drinks.
7. Pack light Pack light so you don't have to pay for checked luggage. Don't be afraid to wash your clothes, reducing the number of outfits you need to take with you.
If it's cheap luggage you're in need of, you can get suitcases from 99p on eBay via their auctions. House of Fraser is also currently offering 50% off luggage in their brand event.
8. Make the most of local transport Avoid organised paid for excursions - it's often cheaper to take local transport and stay for as long as you like.
For cheap train tickets around Europe, you can save up to 40% when you book in advance via the Trainline Europe , with Rome to Venice fares from Â£6.
9. Take lots of holiday snaps Photos are priceless souvenirs of your trip. Enter them in to travel competitions and you might just win flights or another holiday for free!
10. Pack a sun hat It serves as a fashion accessory, doubles as a sick bucket, masks a bad hair day, reserves sun loungers, and hides valuables. Now how much are all those little holiday luxuries worth? The price of a hat!
Want a cheap deal? You can save 50% on selected beach hats this week in the Debenhams fashion sale.
For more holiday hacks, see our Tripadvisor bargain flights guide , or our cheap holidays page for up-to-the minute sales, deals and airline news.
